document_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Sphingomonas Species Associated with the International Space Station
summary_full: This study reports the draft genome sequences of three Sphingomonas strains (two Sphingomonas sanguinis and one Sphingomonas paucimobilis) isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). The genomes were assembled using SPAdes and annotated with the NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline. The sequencing and assembly process involved DNA extraction, library preparation using the Nextera Flex protocol, and whole-genome shotgun sequencing on a NovaSeq 6000. The generated genomic data will facilitate comparative analyses with Earth-based counterparts to understand the influence of microgravity and radiation on their characteristics, such as bioactive compound production and biofilm formation. The raw data and genome sequences are publicly available.
key_findings: Draft genome sequences for two Sphingomonas sanguinis strains and one Sphingomonas paucimobilis strain isolated from the ISS have been assembled.
The genomic data will enable comparative studies to identify genetic factors influenced by the space environment.
Sphingomonas species are known for pollutant degradation, biofilm formation, and potential pathogenicity.
The study provides accession numbers for the genome sequences and raw data in public repositories (NCBI BioProject, GeneLab).
future_research_fields: Comparative genomics of ISS-isolated Sphingomonas with Earth-based strains.
Investigating the genetic basis for altered bioactive compound production under microgravity.
Studying the role of these bacteria in biofilm formation and potential material corrosion in space habitats.
Assessing the potential pathogenicity of ISS-associated Sphingomonas strains in the context of human health in space.
related_papers: Checinska Sielaff A, Urbaniak C, Mohan GBM, Stepanov VG, Tran Q, Wood JM, Minich J, McDonald D, Mayer T, Knight R, Karouia F, Fox GE, Venkateswaran K. 2019. Characterization of the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station surfaces. Microbiome 7:50.
conclusions: The availability of draft genome sequences for Sphingomonas strains isolated from the ISS is a crucial step towards understanding how the space environment influences microbial characteristics, including their potential for producing bioactive compounds and forming biofilms. These sequences will serve as a foundation for future comparative genomic studies.
impact_statement: This research provides essential genomic data for understanding microbial adaptation to space environments, with implications for crew health, life support systems, and the search for novel bioactive compounds.
